document_metadata.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: Considering the importance of protein catabolism in maintaining cell homeostasis, it is not surprising that dysregulation of protein turnover is associated with myriad disease states such as cancer and neurodegeneration [5].

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: Autophagy is an evolutionarily conserved process whose primary task in lower organisms is the maintenance of metabolic homeostasis in the face of changing nutrient availability [8].

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: It has also been suggested that autophagy plays a role in the initiation or progression of some neurodegenerative diseases [20].

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: Insight into the role of autophagy in neurodegeneration has been provided by studies indicating that: 1) some neurodegenerative disease-related proteins are degraded by autophagy, 2) impairment of autophagy promotes neurodegeneration in animal models and several human neurodegenerative diseases, and 3) manipulation of autophagy modifies phenotypes in animal models of neurodegeneration.

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: That neurodegenerative disease-causing proteins are frequently degraded by autophagy was demonstrated by a series of in vitro studies which showed that pharmacological induction or inhibition of macroautophagy alters the rate of turnover of a number of disease-related proteins including polyglutamine-expanded proteins, polyalanine-expanded proteins, as well as wild type and mutant forms of Î±-synuclein [25,26]

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: Pharmacological upregulation of autophagy can be accomplished using the drug rapamycin, which works by inhibiting TOR (target of rapamycin), a pleiotropic molecule that negatively regulates autophagy, among other functions

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: Microautophagy consists of direct engulfment of small volumes of cytosol by lysosomes [10], whereas chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) involves selective, receptor-mediated translocation of proteins into the lysosomal lumen [11].

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: CMA is a process in which proteins harboring a pentapeptide motif related to the sequence KFERQ are specifically recognized by a cytosolic chaperone, the heat shock cognate protein of 70 kDa (hsc70).

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: Even within the category of macroautophagy, there appears to be capability for selectivity, as autophagic processes have been observed that appear to be specific for mitochondria (mitophagy), portions of the nucleus (nucleophagy), peroxisomes (pexophagy), endoplasmic reticulum (reticulophagy), microorganisms (xenophagy), ribosomes (ribophagy) or protein aggregates (aggrephagy) (reviewed in [5]).

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: In mammals, autophagosomes first fuse with endosomes and multivesicular bodies to form amphisomes, which subsequently fuse with lysosomes to create degradative vacuoles termed autolysosomes [17].

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: Although the mechanism whereby autophagy and UPS function are coordinated is little understood, several regulators have emerged as important players in mediating this crosstalk, including histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6) [50,64,75], p62/sequestosome 1 (p62) [76], and the FYVE-domain containing protein Alfy [77]; notably, these proteins have all been found to regulate or be essential for aggresome formation

citation.name: Autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system: collaborators in neuroprotection.

links.evidence: Recent models propose that p62 and HDAC6 function analogously to facilitate autophagic degradation of proteins that display specific polyubiquitin topology.
